STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 12, 2019
Adam Baker
Wayne County DHHS - Northcentral
13233 Hamilton
Highland Park, MI 48203
RE: License #: CP820201495
Wayne County DHHS - Northcentral
13233 Hamilton
Highland Park, MI 48203
Dear Mr. Baker:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
November 20, 2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat non-
compliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R400.12209 Orientation and training.
(1) An agency shall ensure and document that each social
service worker and each social service supervisor receives not
less than 16 hours of orientation after initial appointment and
before assumption of assigned duties.
Twelve of 64 employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 Nine new employee records did not show documentation
of the employee’s orientation to their assigned duties with
the agency.
 Three employee records where the employee was new to
working in a supervisory role did not show documentation
of the employee’s orientation to their new duties.
R400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
Eleven of 64 employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record did not show documentation of a three
month’s probationary evaluation nor a six-month
evaluation due by October 21, 2019.
 A second record showed the employee’s three-month
probationary evaluation for May 18, 2019 and six-month
evaluation for August 18, 2019 were both completed late
on November 6, 2019.
 A third record showed the employee’s three-month
probationary evaluation for May 23,2019 and six-month
evaluation for August 23 ,2019 were both completed late
on November 6, 2019.
 A fourth record showed the employee’s three-month
probationary evaluation for June 23, 2019 and six-month
4

evaluation for September 23, 2019 were both completed
late on November 6, 2019.
 A fifth, sixth and seventh employee records did not show
documentation of the employee’s annual performance
evaluation due by December 31, 2018.
 An eighth, ninth, and tenth employee record showed the
employee’s annual evaluation due by December 31,
2018 was completed late per its respective January 14,
2019, January 11, 2019 and January 11, 2019
completion date.
 An eleventh record showed a typed word document titled
as the employee’s January 1, 2018 to January 31, 2018
annual evaluation. The evaluation did not contain a
completed date nor signature date. I could not discern
whether the evaluation was completed timely.
Repeat Violation- Interim-January 2019, Interim January
2016.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(b) A copy of the job description for the staff member’s current
position.
In four of 64 records reviewed where the employee was
elevated to a supervisory role in 2019, the record did not show a
job description for the employee’s new role.
MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of conditions,
books, records, and reports; access by department, bureau
of fire services, or local authorities; records; report; forms;
confidentiality; disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be provided
to department; failure of licensee to cooperate with
investigation, inspection, or examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department prescribes
regarding each child in its control and care and shall report to
the department, when requested, the facts the department
requires with reference to the children upon forms furnished by
the department. Except as otherwise provided in this subsection
and subsection (4), records regarding children and facts
compiled about children and their parents and relatives are
confidential and disclosure of this information shall be properly
safeguarded by the childcare organization, the department, and
any other entity in possession of the information.
5

Two of eight special evaluation records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record showed documentation of MIC and CPS
language denoting child protective services involvement.
 A second documented the birth mother’s and a siblings’
first and last name.
Repeat Violation- Interim-January 2019, Renewal 2017,
Interim 2016.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as determined
by observation of, and interviews with, each member of the
household and each social service worker who has had children
placed in the home during the last licensing period.
Two of seven open foster home records reviewed did not show
documentation that all workers who had children in the home
over the last licensing period were interviewed.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2016.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
Three of seven open foster home records reviewed showed the
evaluation and recommendation to the department was not
completed at least 15 calendar days before the foster home’s
license expiration date.
Repeat Violation Interim- January 2019, Interim 2016.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
6

(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
One of six borrowed home records reviewed did not show
documentation of (c) and (d) as required by the rule.
(c) is a Repeat Violation-Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
One of six borrowed home records reviewed did not show
documentation of (g) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
One of eight special evaluations reviewed showed the special
investigation record was submitted seven days late.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional time
is required, then the agency shall inform the foster parent, in
writing, of the basis for the extension and the expected length of
the extension. The total time for the completion of the
investigation shall not exceed 90 calendar days without written
approval from the chief administrator or his or her designee.
One of eight special evaluations reviewed showed a 45-day
letter was completed five days late.
7

Repeat Violation- Interim-January-2019, Renewal 2017,
Interim 2016.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons interviewed,
and names of the interviewers. If children are interviewed, their
last names shall not be included in the report.
One of eight special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation the evaluation was completed within 15 days of
its conclusion.
Four of eight special evaluations reviewed did not show
consistent documentation of all places of contacts and of the
interviewer for all interviews and contacts.
Repeat Violation- Interim-January 2019, Renewal 2017.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
(a):
Two of eight special evaluations reviewed did not show
compliance as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2016.
(c):
Two of eight special evaluations reviewed did not show
compliance as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Interim- January 2019.
R 400.12328 Foster home record.
(2) The record shall contain all of the following information:
8

(d) A placement list of all children placed in the foster home,
including all of the following information about each child:
(iii) Date of, and reasons for, a child's removal from the foster
home.
Three of three closed foster home records reviewed did not
show the date of, and reason for, the removal of all children who
had left the foster home.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child's age,
appropriate to the child's capacity to understand, which includes
an explanation to all relevant parties as to why the change is
necessary.
Six of eight closed foster child records and two of eight open
foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of the
child preparation for the change.
Repeat Violation- Interim-January 2019, Renewal 2017,
Interim 2016.
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R 400.12417.
One of eight open foster child record reviewed did not show the
information as required by the rule was provided the caregiver.
Repeat Violation, Interim-January 2019.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to the
time of the change in placement and the needs that remain to
be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
Two of eight closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a) and (b) as required by the rule.
9

Repeat Violation, Interim-January 2019.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the
child re-entered care August 14, 2019. (A prior medical was
documented for October 3, 2017). The child’s medical was
completed late on November 2019.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111. All of the
following apply:
(i) A statement from a parent or licensed medical authority
which indicates that immunizations are current or
contraindicated is sufficient documentation of immunizations.
(ii) A copy of a waiver addressed to the department of
community health signed by the parent stating immunizations
are not being administered due to religious, medical, or other
reasons is sufficient documentation of immunizations.
(iii) If documentation of immunization or a copy of the
waiver is unavailable, then immunizations shall begin within 30
calendar days of placement.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed as of
July 14, 2019, the child’s DTP/DTaP/DT/Td/Tdap, HPV and
meningococcal were past due.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
10

(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Of 25 updated service plans (USP) reviewed five were late by:
 One day.
 Two days.
 Seven days.
 Eight days.
 Sixty-three days.
Repeat Violation, Interim-January 2019, Renewal 2017,
Interim 2016.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(6) Service plans shall be signed by the social services worker
and the social services supervisor.
One of 28 service plans reviewed did not show documentation
of the supervisor’s signature.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at least once
every month.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of January 2019 foster home visit.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MSA violation. Please note that there
are additional MSA requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional MSA requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
11

Two of seven open foster home records reviewed did not show
uploads of all documents related to the foster home’s special
evaluation (i.e. open and closing DHS-259, signed special
evaluation, conclusion letter to the foster family).
Four of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
consistent documentation that each signed service plan, signed
parent/agency treatment plan agreement, family team meeting
(FTM) and DHS-1105 were uploaded to MISACWIS.
Repeat Violation Interim-January 2019, Renewal 2017,
Interim 2016.
ISEP 6.33 Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Four of 28 service plans reviewed were not signed by the birth
parent.
Two of 28 service plans reviewed where the youth was fourteen
years or older, did not contain the youth’s signature.
Repeat Violation, Interim-January 2019, Renewal 2017,
Interim 2016.
ISEP 6.49 6.49 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, and
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors) and
provided to the foster care provider.
Four of eight open foster child records reviewed via MISACWIS
did not show compliance:
12

 One record did not show documentation of updated
medical passports, or that such were provided the
caregiver.
 A second record did not show documentation of a
December 2018 or September 2019 quarterly updated
medical passports.
 A third record did not show documentation of an August
2019 quarterly medical passport or that such was
provided the caregiver.
 A fourth record did not show documentation of a medical
passport for the child.
Repeat Violation- Interim January-2019, Renewal 2017,
Interim 2016.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
Policy FOM 722- Family Team Meeting.
6 B
Types and Timeframes
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
-Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Note: This FTM may be combined with the CPS Case Opening
(ISP) FTM.
-Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
-Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Five of 28 service plans reviewed did not show compliance:
 One record did not show documentation of an FTM for
service plan February 13, 2019 to May 8, 2019 or May 9,
2019 to August 6, 2019.
 A second record showed documentation of an FTM for
the child’s change of placement on February 15, 2019,
13

yet the DHS-1105 was blank. Additionally, this record did
not show documentation of an FTM for the child’s change
of placement on March 11, 2019 or return home on
September 26, 2019.
 A third record did not show documentation of an FTM for
service plan February 28, 2019 to May 28, 2019.
Additionally, this record did not show documentation of a
DHS-1105 for an FTM listed as July 9, 2019, nor
documentation in MISACWIS of the outcome of that
FTM.
 A fourth record did not show documentation of a DHS-
1105 for an FTM listed as February 25, 2019, nor
documentation in MISACWIS of the outcome of that
FTM.
 A fifth record did not show documentation of an FTM for
service plan period February 28, 2019 to May 28, 2019.
A December 14, 2018 FTM was documented for the
service period November 30, 2018 to February 27, 2019,
yet it was outside the timeframe specified by the policy
standard.
Repeat Violation- Interim-January 2019, Renewal 2017,
Interim 2016.
Policy FOM 722- Maintaining Connections: Parenting Time, Sibling
6I Visitation, and contact.
Required Supervision by the Caseworker
If parenting time is supervised by individuals other than the
assigned caseworker, the assigned caseworker must observe
parenting time at least once during the first 30 days after
removal and once per quarter thereafter to assess parenting
skills and attachment.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
consistent documentation of the worker personally supervising
at least one parent/child visitation per month.
Policy FOM 722- Foster Care- Initial Service Plan.
8
Supervisory Approval:
Review and approve the ISP within 14 calendar days of the
Report Date.
One of three initial service plans reviewed was approved three
days late.
14

Repeat Violation- Interim-January 2019, Renewal 2017,
Interim 2016.
Policy FOM 722- Foster Care - Parent-Agency Treatment Plan & Service
8C Agreement.
Signatures:
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS
office designee.
Six of 28 service plans reviewed did not show documentation of
the foster parent/caregiver’s signature.
Repeat Violation, Interim- January 2019, Renewal 2017,
Interim 2016.
Policy FOM 722- Foster Care- Updated Service Plan.
9
Supervisory Approval:
Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report.
Three of 25 USP(s) were late by:
 19 days.
 21 days.
 68 days.
Repeat Violation- Interim- January 2019, Interim 2016.
Policy FOM 722- Foster Care Action Summary.
09 C
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a case.
The foster care action summary is generated from SWSS FAJ.
The DHS worker must complete the DHS-69, Action Summary
(RFF 69) in SWSS. Child placing agencies will continue to use
the DHS-69, Action Summary template. This form also serves
as notice to the courts of changes in placements, parent's living
situation and the FC worker/agency, as identifying information is
indicated. The FC/JJ action summary meets licensing
requirements for replacement documentation (See FOM 722-
03) and in most cases, agency transfer and case closing
summary (see below). The FC/JJ action summary must also be
used for foster care transfer to adoption.
15

Which Cases/ When What does this mean
All foster care cases where there is:
 A replacement.
 Case closing.
Seven of eight closed foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record did not show documentation of a DHS-69 for
the child’s move to a stepparent on December 3, 2018.
 A second did not show documentation of a DHS-69 for
the child’s return home on June 20, 2019 or case closure
on September 16, 2019.
 A third record did not show documentation of a DHS-69
for the child’s return home on April 5, 2019 and case
closure on April 29, 2019.
 A fourth record did not show documentation of a DHS-69
for the child’s return home on March 29, 2019.
Additionally, the DHS-69 for the child’s case closure was
completed late on October 9, 2019 for an effective case
closure date of June 4, 2019.
 Three other closed foster child records reviewed showed
the DHS-69 for the child’s case closure was completed
more than three calendar day after the respective child’s,
July 3, 2019 (completed August 15, 2019) August 9,
2019(completed November 6, 2019) and October 8,
2018(completed December 16, 2018) case closure date.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record did not show documentation of a DHS-69 for
the child’s replacement on January 9, 2019. Additionally,
this record showed a late DHS-69 for the child’s
replacement on January 4, 2019. The DHS-69 was
completed November 20, 2019.
 A second record did not show documentation of a DHS-
69 for the child’s replacement to the birth home on
September 26, 2019.
Repeat Violation, Interim-January 2019, Renewal 2017,
Interim 2016.
Policy FOM Case Closure Discharge Document.
722.15
Discharge Documents
For all other children, the caseworker must provide a copy of
educational documents, Social Security card, birth certificate
and the completed medical passport to the birth parent or
16

guardian at the time of closure; see FOM 801, Medical
Passports and FOM 723, Educational Services. For adoptive
placements, the caseworker must provide copies of any
additional documents that have been obtained since the
adoption referral to the adoption worker; see ADM 0210,
Notification from Foster Care.
One of eight closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation that all documents required by the rule were
provided to the birth parent.
Repeat Violation-Interim-January 2019.
CI 16-182a Communication Issuance.
Security Awareness Training for Fingerprint Base Criminal
History Requirements
Security Awareness Training (SAT) is required for authorized
personnel who have been granted access to fingerprint-based
Criminal History Record Information (CHRI). This training
provides information on what fingerprint based CHRI is, who
has access, how to ensure this information remains secure both
physically an electronically, and how you can use this
information appropriately.
All non-contracted and governmental CPA employees,
subcontractors, subcontractor’s employees or volunteers who
are authorized to have access to fingerprint based CHRI must
successfully complete SAT within six months of appointment to
a position with CHRI access and every two years thereafter.
One of 13 current employees listed as having access to CHRI
showed the employee’s training due by January 27, 2019 was
completed late on March 13, 2019.
Repeat Violation, Interim-January 2019.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12420(1)(e) Updated service plan
 The child’s narrative sections of the parent agency treatment plan agreement
must accurately and consistently reflect the information as reported in social
works contacts.
17

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Nothing at this time.
18

EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated maltreatment in care during the licensing
period:
The incident related to an allegation that foster parents/relatives hit a foster child in
the head with a cell phone and physically disciplined the child with a spatula for
misbehaving. The investigation found evidence the foster child was hit in the head
with a cell phone and physically hit by the foster parents/relatives. The foster home
was found in noncompliance with the behavior management rule related to the use
of corporal punishment. The agency recommended revocation of the foster home’s
license.
The agency actions appeared appropriated in this instance. The agency adhered to
all departmental requirements except MCL 722.120(3) as indicated earlier in this
report.
There was one incident of behavior management during the licensing period:
The incident related to an allegation that the foster parent whooped the foster child
because the child hit another child. The investigation did not find the foster parent in
noncompliance related to the allegation. The foster parent admitted to threatening to
physically hit the child. The foster parent was found in violation of the foster parent’s
duties rule and the agency’s policy related to behavior management. A corrective
action plan was completed.
The agency adhered to all departmental requirements except R400.1237 (5) (d) and
R400.1237(6)(a) as indicated earlier in this report.
AND
The agency submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period:
The corrective action related to the agency’s January 2019 Interim Inspection. The
agency received, one personnel citation, 20 rule citations, six ISEP citations, eight
policy citations, and one communication issuance citation. The agency received a
deceased in the number of rule and ISEP violations this inspection. However, the
agency received several repeat violations. The agency experienced continued
staffing changes this inspection. The agency’s prior district manager returned to the
agency and a number of worker and supervisory staff changes occurred. The
agency reports continued teamwork and that employees are adjusting to the
changing staffing.
DCWL ANALYST CONCERNS ADDRESSED:
Safety Alert October 14, 2019:
19

Concern:
Smoke detector on the lower level was inoperable. The smoke detector was beeping in
the hallway near the bedroom.
Resolution:
The agency contacted the family related to this concern. The foster home has two
smoke detectors on the main floor. The one in the foster parent’s bedroom was tested
and operable. The chirping device was removed and replaced; the licensing worker
installed a new smoke and carbon monoxide detector. Another carbon monoxide
detector is located in the kitchen; and a third smoke detector is located on the second
level. All devices were tested and are operable.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
December 10, 2019
